quiz.name: Module 9: The Term Structure of Interest Rates: Spot, Par, and Forward Curves
quiz.subtopic: Module 9: The Term Structure of Interest Rates: Spot, Par, and Forward Curves

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Barker-02
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about spot rates:

Time to Maturity Sequence 1 Sequence 2
1 year 2.0% 4.7%
2 years 3.5% 3.5%
3 years 4.7% 2.0%

For a 3-year, 2% annual coupon payment bond, the price using Sequence 1 is:

answerFeedback.000c8726-1c2c-4152-94c6-9fc29d619d43:
Incorrect because for Sequence 1, applying this formula, the bond price is: (2/1.02) + (2/1.0712) + (102/1.1477) = 1.9608 + 1.8670 + 88.871 ≈ 92.70.

For Sequence 2, the bond price is: (2/1.047) + (2/1.712) + (102/1.0612) = 1.9608 + 1.8674 + 96.1169 ≈ 99.89.  

The bond price using Sequence 1 is less than the price using Sequence 2.
answerFeedback.5084068e-ccff-43d5-9491-2e73350e4dc4:
Correct because the formula to calculate a bond price given a sequence of spot rates is the following: PV =(PMT / (1+Z1)1) + (PMT / (1+Z2)2) + … + (PMT + FV) / (1+ZN)N), where
Z1 = spot rate, or zero-coupon yield, or zero rate, for Period 1
Z2 = spot rate, or zero-coupon yield, or zero rate, for Period 2
ZN = spot rate, or zero-coupon yield, or zero rate, for Period N. 

For Sequence 1, applying this formula, the bond price is: (2/1.02) + (2/1.0712) + (102/1.1477) = 1.9608 + 1.8670 + 88.871 ≈ 92.70.

For Sequence 2, the bond price is: (2/1.047) + (2/1.712) + (102/1.0612) = 1.9608 + 1.8674 + 96.1169 ≈ 99.89.  

The bond price using Sequence 1 is less than the price using Sequence 2.
answerFeedback.6a911eb8-a641-491a-bd13-64d594ed758d:
Incorrect because for Sequence 1, applying this formula, the bond price is: (2/1.02) + (2/1.0712) + (102/1.1477) = 1.9608 + 1.8670 + 88.871 ≈ 92.70.

For Sequence 2, the bond price is: (2/1.047) + (2/1.712) + (102/1.0612) = 1.9608 + 1.8674 + 96.1169 ≈ 99.89.  

The bond price using Sequence 1 is less than the price using Sequence 2.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the price using Sequence 2.
B. the same as the price using Sequence 2.
C. greater than the price using Sequence 2.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-11014
entry.itemBody: Implied forward rates are best defined as the:

answerFeedback.1f4cf22d-5d5e-4377-87a5-6485009b87a4: Incorrect because the spot curve can be calculated as the geometric average of the forward rates.
answerFeedback.788e0c9b-9de6-49a9-996c-b797f834a482: Incorrect because spot rates are yields-to-maturity on zero-coupon bonds maturing at the date of each cash flow.
answerFeedback.f4a2647b-8332-4d97-9627-c7eae3ef395c: Correct because implied forward rates (also known as forward yields) are calculated from spot rates. An implied forward rate is a break-even reinvestment rate. When the market is in equilibrium (no arbitrage) the implied forward rate is the same as the forward rate.

choices.itemBody: B. breakeven reinvestment rates between zero-coupon bonds.
C. current yield to maturity on zero-coupon bonds of different maturities.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09667
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a spot curve:

Term to Maturity Spot Rate
1 year 6%
2 years 5%
3 years 4%

If the coupon rate of a 3-year annual-pay bond is 4%, the price of the bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.17325bb3-d764-464c-8ace-21a603eb938b: Incorrect because the price of the bond is calculated using the 3-year spot rate as discount rate for all cash flows. Hence, PV ≠ 4/(1 + 0.04)1 + 4/(1 + 0.04)2 + (4 + 100)/(1 + 0.04)3 = 4/1.04 + 4/1.0816 + 104/1.1249 = 3.8461+ 3.6982+ 92.4527 = 99.9969 ≈ 100.00.
answerFeedback.df4fd7e0-df20-4953-ab99-cd9dba73dd9b: Correct because given the spot rates, the price of a bond can be calculated using the following formula: PV = [PMT/(1 + Z1)1 + PMT/(1 + Z2)2 + …+ (PMT + FV)/(1 + ZN)N] Hence, PV = 4/(1 + 0.06)1 + 4/(1 + 0.05)2 + (4 + 100)/(1 + 0.04)3 = 4/1.06 + 4/1.1025 + 104/1.1249 = 3.77358+ 3.62812 + 92.4556 = 99.8573 ≈ 99.86.
answerFeedback.e613403c-54ef-4452-85cc-0448d6f0de70:
Incorrect because the price of the bond is calculated using as discount rates the average of the spot rates; (6% + 5% +4%)/3 = 15%/3= 5%. Hence,

PV ≠ 4/(1.05)1 + 4/(1.05)2 + 104/(1.05)3 = 4/1.05 + 4/1.1025 + 104/1.157625 = 3.8095+ 3.6281 + 89.8391= 97.276 ≈ 97.28.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FI-Garcia-Huidobro-06
entry.itemBody: A bond trading at its no-arbitrage value is priced at a premium. The sum of the present value of the bond's cash flows discounted at spot rates is:

answerFeedback.033c1c30-0756-4694-afc7-11e32d924600:
Incorrect because bond price (or value) determined using the spot rates is sometimes referred to as the bond’s 'no-arbitrage value'.

If the current market price equals the no-arbitrage value, discounting the cash flows by either spot rates or yield to maturity arrives to the same price. The level of the current market price vis a vis par has no bearing the no-arbitrage value.
answerFeedback.03d55030-d61c-4693-be6e-0c6746d998d2:
Correct because bond price (or value) determined using the spot rates is sometimes referred to as the bond’s 'no-arbitrage value'.

If the current market price equals the 'no-arbitrage value, discounting the cash flows by either spot rates or yield to maturity arrives to the same price.
answerFeedback.da7ff724-34ac-4e0e-ad60-a0c2a480549d:
Incorrect because the bond price (or value) determined using the spot rates is sometimes referred to as the bond’s 'no-arbitrage value'.

If the current market price equals the no-arbitrage value, discounting the cash flows by either spot rates or yield to maturity arrives to the same price. The level of the current market price vis a vis par has no bearing the no-arbitrage value.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the sum of the present values of the bond's cash flows discounted at its yield to maturity.
B. equal to the sum of the present values of the bond's cash flows discounted at its yield to maturity.
C. greater than the sum of the present values of the bond's cash flows discounted at its yield to maturity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FI-Mazur-16
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following spot and forward rates:

2-year spot rate 1.0%
4-year spot rate 2.5%
4-year forward rate, two years from today 3.0%

The 2-year forward rate, four years from today is closest to:

answerFeedback.0b30e22c-663f-4261-be48-6ba68d98d2f2:
Correct because the general formula for the relationship between two spot rates and the implied forward rate is: (1 + zA)A × (1 + IFRA,B-A)B-A = (1 + zB)B, where zx is the x-year spot rate and IFRx,y is the y-year forward rate, x years from now. Using the formula, the 6 year spot rate can be calculated in two different ways:

1. Using A = 2, B = 6: (1 + z6)6 = (1 + z2)2 × (1 + IFR2,4)4 

2. Using A = 4, B = 6: (1 + z6)6 = (1 + z4)4 × (1 + IFR4,2)2 

Equating the two we get: (1 + z2)2 × (1 + IFR2,4)4 = (1 + z4)4 × (1 + IFR4,2)2 . Using the numbers from the stem:

(1 + 0.01)2 × (1 + 0.03)4 = (1 + 0.025)4 × (1 + IFR4,2)2

1.0201 × 1.1255 = 1.1038 × (1 + IFR4,2)2

⇒ IFR4,2 = (1.1481/1.1038)0.5 – 1 = 0.0199 ≈ 2%.
answerFeedback.8ef09aab-2494-42bc-bf86-8c84714d9311: Incorrect because instead of using the formula for the relationship between spot rates and the implied forward rates, the candidate assumed that the 2 year forward rate, 4 years from today is equal to the 4 year forward rate, 2 years from today.
answerFeedback.f7634ff5-fbdb-45f9-ab17-2ba994aa7ea8: Incorrect because when calculating IFR4,2, in the last step, the candidate forgets to take the square root. IFR4,2 ≠ 1.1481/1.1038 – 1 = 0.0401 ≈ 4%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02874
entry.itemBody: A break-even reinvestment rate is most likely equivalent to a(n):

answerFeedback.0a0d97f6-913c-4220-bcf1-d92da6ecbbb7: Incorrect because a par curve is a sequence of yields-to-maturity such that each bond is priced at par value. Par rates are not break-even reinvestment rates.
answerFeedback.280e34d3-fd51-4df1-b3e8-720cdefbe74b: Correct because an implied forward rate is a break-even reinvestment rate. It links the return on an investment in a shorter-term zero-coupon bond to the return on an investment in a longer-term zero-coupon bond.
answerFeedback.430b0a71-16ce-4838-a7a3-fd7d8c9325ff: Incorrect because the spot rate is a sequence of yields-to-maturity on zero-coupon bonds. A forward rate links one spot rate to another and for this reason can be characterized as a break-even reinvestment rate. A spot rate alone is, however, not a break-even reinvestment rate.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06450
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about forward rates:

Time Period Forward Rate
0y1y 1%
1y1y 2%
2y1y 4%

Using only this information, the price per 100 of par value of a 3-year, 1% annual coupon bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.31a434a7-bdd0-4625-9ed4-0a2e9cac97ff:
Incorrect because the forward rates are used directly as spot rates. Hence,

PV ≠ PMT / (1 + Z1)1 + PMT / (1 + Z2)2 + … + (PMT + FV) / (1 + ZN)N

PV ≠ 1 / (1 + 1%)1 + 1 / (1 + 2%)2 + (1 + 100) / (1 + 4%)3 = 0.9901 + 0.9612 +89.7886 = 91.7399, rounded to 91.74.
answerFeedback.637be804-bb1a-4c0b-877a-38bb11dde12d:
Correct because the geometric average of the forward rates gives us the spot rates (ie. (0y1y × 1y1y) = (1 + Z2)2, (0y1y × 1y1y × 2y1y) = (1 + Z3)3)), hence the price of a bond using forward rates can be calculated using: PV = PMT / (1 + Z1)1 + PMT / (1 + Z2)2 + … + (PMT + FV) / (1 + ZN)N where Z1 = spot rate, or the zero-coupon yield, or zero rate, for Period 1, Z2 = spot rate, or the zero-coupon yield, or zero rate, for Period 2, ZN = spot rate, or the zero-coupon yield, or zero rate, for Period N.

PV> = PMT / (1 + 0y1y) + PMT / (1 + 0y1y × 1y1y) + (PMT + FV) / (1 + 0y1y × 1y1y × 2y1y)

PV = 1 / (1 + 1%) + 1 / ((1 + 1%)(1 + 2%)) + (1 + 100) / ((1 + 1%)(1 + 2%)(1 + 4%) = 0.9901 + 0.9707 +94.2685 = 96.2293, rounded to 96.23.
answerFeedback.6e9617cb-a842-4833-88fa-0f97019af87d:
Incorrect because each denominator is raised to the power of the corresponding year.

PV ≠ PMT / (1 + 0y1y) + PMT / (1 + 0y1y × 1y1y)2 + (PMT + FV) / (1 + 0y1y × 1y1y × 2y1y)3

PV ≠ 1 / (1 + 1%) + 1 / ((1 + 1%)(1 + 2%))2 + (1 + 100) / ((1 + 1%)(1 + 2%)(1 + 4%))3 = 0.9901 + 0.9422 +82.1215 = 84.0538, rounded to 84.05.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05933
entry.itemBody:
An analyst observes the following series of 1-year forward rates:

Time Period Forward Rate
0y1y 0.1%
1y1y 0.3%
2y1y 0.6%

Based on only this information, the price per 100 of par value of a 3-year 0.2% annual coupon bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.3a092f13-d780-4c9c-845b-6d4cfceff580:
Incorrect because the bond is priced on the basis of spot rates rather than forward rates:

Price per 100 of par value ≠ 0.2 / (1+0.1%)1 + 0.2 / (1+0.3%)2 + (100+0.2) / (1+0.6%)3 = 98.82.
answerFeedback.7a3ac042-5825-4fd7-816e-fa1e81fd9ddf:
Incorrect because the denominator of each term is incorrectly raised to a power:

Price per 100 of par value ≠ 0.2 / (1+0.1%)1 + 0.2 / ((1+0.1%) × (1+0.3%))2 + (100+0.2) / ((1+0.1%) × (1+0.3%)× (1+0.6%))3 = 97.64.

entry.body:
Use the spot rates provided to answer the following questions.

Government Bond Spot Rates

Maturity Canada Australia Germany Switzerland
1-year 0.3117% 0.0272% –0.6965% –0.7882%
2-year 0.5680% 0.0675% –0.7034% –0.7133%
3-year 0.7977% 0.3003% –0.7021% –0.6435%
4-year 0.9640% 0.5853% –0.6418% –0.5615%
5-year 1.1105% 0.8052% –0.5578% –0.4757%
6-year 1.2052% 0.9877% –0.4796% –0.4080%
7-year 1.2998% 1.1702% –0.4014% –0.3402%
8-year 1.3935% 1.2878% –0.3269% –0.2673%
9-year 1.4872% 1.4054% –0.2524% –0.1945%
10-year 1.5809% 1.5230% –0.1779% –0.1216%
entry.title: Vignette
CFA2439-R-s04-Q5

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Given that Switzerland’s current five-year spot (and par) rate is negative, any non-negative coupon will cause the Swiss government to issue debt at a premium to par. Issuance of debt without a coupon will minimize the size of the premium.

entry.itemBody: Which level of coupon would the Swiss government choose if its goal is to minimize the premium over par value for a five-year debt issue?

entry.title: CFA2439-R-s04-Q6

feedback.neutral:
B is correct.

P V = P M T ( 1 + Z 1 ) 1 + P M T ( 1 + Z 2 ) 2 + ⋯ + P M T + F V ( 1 + Z N ) N .
P V = 3 ( 1 + 0.000272 ) 1 + 3 ( 1 + 0.000675 ) 2 + 103 ( 1 + 0.003003 ) 3 .
PV = 108.07.

entry.itemBody: The Australian government is considering issuing three-year bonds with a 3.0% coupon with annual payments. Given the spot rates in Australia, the price is closest to:

entry.title: CFA2439-R-s04-Q7

feedback.neutral: C is correct. In Example 2, we calculated the three-year Canadian par rate. The par rate of 0.7952% approximates the spot rate of 0.7977%, so the most important change affecting the three-year par rate is the change in the three-year spot rate. Because it does not change, the only change will be a slight move in the par rate toward the spot rate (to approximately 0.7968%).

entry.itemBody: Suppose the one-year and two-year spot rates in Canada move upward by 20 bps but the three-year Canadian spot rate remains unchanged. Which of the following best reflects the updated three-year Canadian par rate?

entry.title: CFA2439-R-s04-Q8

feedback.neutral:
1. B. By using two-year and five-year rates, the difference represents the tenor of the implied forward rate of three years, and the shorter tenor rate reflects the beginning of the forward in two years.

2. C. By using two-year and seven-year rates, the difference represents the tenor of the implied forward rate of five years, and the shorter tenor rate reflects the beginning of the forward in two years.

3. A. By using five-year and seven-year rates, the difference represents the tenor of the implied forward rate of two years, and the shorter tenor rate reflects the beginning of the forward in five years.

entry.itemBody:
Match the spot rates needed to calculate the corresponding implied forward rates.

1. Two-year and five-year spot rates A. Two-year implied forward rate in five years
2. Two-year and seven-year spot rates B. Three-year implied forward rate in two years
3. Five-year and seven-year spot rates C. Five-year implied forward rate in two years

entry.title: CFA2439-R-s04-Q9

feedback.neutral:
The correct answer is A. The implied five-year forward rate in two years is the 2y5y rate. To calculate, we use the seven-year Swiss government rate and the two-year Swiss government rate, as follows:

2y5y IFR = [(1 – 0.003402)7/(1 – 0.007133)2](1/5) – 1 = 0.191%.

Choice B represents the 5y2y implied forward rate, and Choice C represents the 2y3y implied forward rate.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following choices is the closest to the implied five-year forward rate in two years for Swiss government bonds?

entry.title: CFA2439-R-s04-Q10

feedback.neutral:
1. B. This is a series of three one-year forwards, thus providing the information for a three-year spot rate.

2. C. This sequence is a one-year spot rate, followed by a two-year forward rate in one year, followed by a three-year forward rate in three years.

3. A. This sequence is a series of four one-year forwards.

entry.itemBody:
Match the sequence of forward rates and the corresponding spot rate that the forward rates will calculate.

Forward rates Spot rate calculation
1. 0y1y x 1y1y x 2y1y A. Four-year spot rate
2. 0y1y x 1y2y x 3y3y B. Three-year spot rate
3. 0y1y x 1y1y x 2y1y x 3y1y C. Six-year spot rate

entry.title: CFA2439-R-s04-Q11

feedback.neutral: The correct answer is C. The forward rates used to construct forward curves are derived from spot rates. Statement A is not true, because par rates are derived from spot rates. Statement B is not true, because par curves are derived from spot rates.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about yield curves is true?

choices.itemBody: A. Spot curves are derived from par rates.
B. Par curves are derived from forward rates.
C. Forward curves are derived from spot rates.

entry.title: CFA2439-R-s04-Q12

feedback.neutral:
1. B. In a normal interest rate environment with an upward-sloping yield curve, forward interest rates will be greater than their corresponding spot rates across all maturities.

2. A. In an inverted spot rate environment, forward interest rates will be below their corresponding spot rates.

3. C. A flat maturity structure of interest rates is sometimes assumed. In such an environment in which spot rates are constant, this implies that future expectations are for interest rates to remain at a constant level. Thus, forward rates equal spot rates in a flat term structure environment.

entry.itemBody:
Match the following statements about forward rate curves with corresponding statements about spot rate curves.

1. The forward rate curve lies above the spot rate curve. A. The spot rate curve is downward sloping (i.e., inverted).
2. The forward rate curve lies below the spot rate curve. B. The spot rate curve is upward sloping (i.e., normal).
3. The forward rate curve is equivalent to the spot rate curve. C. The spot rate curve is flat across all maturities.

entry.title: CFA2439-R-s04-Q13

feedback.neutral:
1. A. This situation is illustrated in the German and Swiss government interest rate data in which spot rates are negative while the spot rate curve is upward sloping. In such instances, par rates lie above spot rates.

2. B. This situation is illustrated in the Canadian and Australian government interest rate data in which spot rates are positive and the spot curve is normal.

3. C. This is a hypothetical case but can be seen by creating a flat spot rate curve.

entry.itemBody:
Match the following statements about par rate curves with corresponding statements about spot rate curves.

1. The par rate curve lies above the spot rate curve. A. The spot rate curve is upward sloping (i.e., normal), and spot rates are negative.
2. The par rate curve lies below the spot rate curve. B. The spot rate curve is upward sloping (i.e., normal), and spot rates are positive.
3. The par rate curve is equivalent to the spot rate curve. C. The spot rate curve is flat across all maturities.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607006
entry.itemBody:
Using the following US Treasury spot rates, the arbitrage-free value of a two-year $100 par value Treasury bond with a 6% coupon rate, paid semi-annually, is closest to:
Period Years Spot Rate (Annualized)
1 0.5 1.60%
2 1.0 2.20%
3 1.5 2.70%
4 2.0 3.10%

answerFeedback.7b86012c-132c-4a47-aa48-9e7d384c4569: Incorrect because it treats the spot rates as forward rates.
answerFeedback.84f15bf0-1618-4a5f-8080-76dcb6c0dce9:
Correct because the value of the bond is

3 ( 1+ 0.0160/2 ) 1 + 3 ( 1+ 0.0220/2 ) 2 + 3 ( 1+ 0.0270/2 ) 3 + 103 ( 1+ 0.0310/2 ) 4 =105.65
answerFeedback.bed8d988-d044-4e7e-ac97-1103082edfea: Incorrect because it does not divide the annual spot rates by two in the calculation.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607011
entry.itemBody: A two-year spot rate of 5% is most likely the:

answerFeedback.27fa39e4-5246-4c82-a8d2-fc7b50b7113b: Correct because the spot rate is defined as the yield to maturity on a zero-coupon bond maturing at the date of that cash flow.
answerFeedback.d27d87b0-fa09-4917-930a-4aac8d9384c5: Incorrect because the spot rate is the yield to maturity on a zero-coupon bond maturing at that point in time and not the yield to maturity on a coupon-paying bond.
answerFeedback.ecb17f48-61a0-4beb-81b7-c6725e278182: Incorrect because the spot rate is the yield to maturity on a zero-coupon bond maturing at that point in time and not the coupon rate on a coupon-paying bond.

choices.itemBody: A. yield to maturity on a zero-coupon bond maturing at the end of Year 2.
B. yield to maturity on a coupon-paying bond maturing at the end of Year 2.
C. coupon rate in Year 2 on a coupon-paying bond maturing at the end of Year 4.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607014
entry.itemBody:
Assume the following annual forward rates were calculated from the yield curve.
Time Period Forward Rate
0y1y 0.50%
1y1y 0.70%
2y1y 1.00%
3y1y 1.50%
4y1y 2.20%

The four-year spot rate is closest to:

answerFeedback.65640304-8709-41bb-add8-adf0eac37a20:
Incorrect because it is computed as:

[ ( 1.005 )×( 1.007 )×( 1.01 )×( 1.015 )×( 1.022 ) ] 1/5 −1=1.178%
answerFeedback.d833abb4-420b-46ba-96e0-9b5d3bd47af7:
Incorrect because it is computed as:

[ ( 1.007 )×( 1.01 )×( 1.015 )×( 1.022 ) ] 1/4 −1=1.348%
answerFeedback.efd7bfbc-a7a0-4fdc-91e1-0e7cc5821865:
Correct. The four-year spot rate can be computed as:

z 4 = [ ( 1.005 )×( 1.007 )×( 1.01 )×( 1.015 ) ] 1/4 −1=0.924%

entry.title: ITEM_20170607053
entry.itemBody:
Using the following US Treasury forward rates, the value of a 2.5-year $100 par value Treasury bond with a 5% coupon rate is closest to:
Period Years Forward Rate
1 0.5 1.20%
2 1 1.80%
3 1.5 2.30%
4 2 2.70%
5 2.5 3.00%

answerFeedback.3381fa95-e751-4f23-8fe9-0745a15bb69d: Incorrect because it treats the forward rates as spot rates.
answerFeedback.babc3e9f-9ac5-4bde-b512-adfe655735dc:
Correct. The value of the bond is

2.5 ( 1+ 0.012/2 ) + 2.5 ( 1+ 0.012/2 )×( 1+ 0.18/2 ) + 2.5 ( 1+ 0.012/2 )×( 1+ 0.018/2 )×( 1+ 0.023/2 ) + 2.5 ( 1+ 0.012/2 )×( 1+ 0.018/2 )×( 1+ 0.023/2 )×( 1+ 0.027/2 ) + 102.5 ( 1+ 0.012/2 )×( 1+ 0.018/2 )×( 1+ 0.023/2 )×( 1+ 0.027/2 )×( 1+ 0.030/2 ) =$106.83
answerFeedback.d664b3c1-1ef0-4cf8-9c01-32f7f10786a5: Incorrect because it does not divide the forward rates by two.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607103
entry.itemBody:
Eldora Ltd. recently issued deferred-coupon bonds for which no coupon payments will be paid in the first two years of the bond’s life. Regular annual coupon payments at a rate of 9% will then be made until the bonds mature at the end of six years. The spot rates for various maturities are given in the following table.
Time to Maturity Spot Rate
1 year 8.0%
2 years 7.5%
3 years 7.0%
4 years 6.5%
5 years 6.0%
6 years 5.5%

On the basis of these spot rates, the price of the bond today is closest to:

answerFeedback.b4a8427d-e7a6-406b-8d55-d7737cee1fbc:
Correct. The bond price is computed as

P0 = 9/(1.070)3 + 9/(1.065)4 + 9/(1.060)5 + (9 + 100)/(1.055)6 = 100.12
answerFeedback.c8feb840-cf93-4f2c-9f5b-fec5026afe7c:
Incorrect because the price is computed assuming that the coupons are paid over years 1 through 4 and the par value is paid in year four, as follows:

P0 = 9/(1.080)1 + 9/(1.075)2 + 9/(1.070)3 + (9 + 100)/(1.065)4 = 108.196
answerFeedback.f9bf5519-c200-46d5-975c-d0dd53c62e3a:
Incorrect because the price is computed assuming that the coupons are paid over years 1 through 6 and the par value is paid at maturity in year six, as follows:

P0 = 9/(1.080)1 + 9/(1.075)2 + … + (9 + 100)/(1.055)6 = 116.241

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10098
entry.itemBody:
An analyst observes the following yields to maturity on zero-coupon government bonds:

Maturity Yield to Maturity
1 year 1.5%
2 years 2.5%
3 years 3.5%

The 2y1y implied forward rate is closest to:

answerFeedback.3c3624c6-ec1c-4622-9479-3701de564dee: Incorrect because it is the compounded three year to maturity bond divided by the product of the first two yields to maturity. The yield is found as (1 + z1) × (1 + z2) ×(1 + IFR1,2) = (1 + z3)3 = (1 + 0.015) × (1 + 0.025) × (1 + IFR1,2) = (1 + 1.035)3. (1 + IFR1,2)2 = (1 + 1.040)3 / [(1 + 0.015) × (1.025)] – 1 = 1.1087 / 1.0404 = 1.0656 – 1 = 0.0656 or 6.6%.
answerFeedback.59f6ed61-85ac-47cf-ae41-c312647dd50e: Correct because the 2y1y yield is the implied one-year forward yield two years from now. The 2y1y implied yield can be found using (1 + z2)2 × (1 + IFR2,1)1 = (1 + z3)3 = (1 + 0.025)2 × (1 + IFR2,1)1 = (1 + 1.035)3. IFR2,1 = (1 + 1.035)3 / (1 + 0.025)2 – 1 = 1.1087 / 1.0506 – 1 = 0.0553 = 5.53%.
answerFeedback.cd052c54-b67a-4b0e-8ff2-cdf29024bea0: Incorrect because it is the 1y2y implied forward yield. The yield can be found using (1 + z1)1 × (1 + IFR1,2)2 = (1 + z3)3; (1 + 0.015)1× (1 + IFR1,2)2 = (1 + 0.035)3× (1 + IFR1,2)2 = (1 + 0.035)3 / (1 + 0.015)1 – 1 = 1.1087 / 1.0150 = 1.0923. IFR1,2 = 1.0923½ – 1 = 0.0451 or 4.51%.
